body:
Hi Alexey, thanks for the report. `LogicalCallContext` and remoting has been an absolute nightmare for this feature, we thought we finally had a bulletproof implementation in 2.0 but it seems we're not so lucky :( // cc @colin-young @DmitryNaumov @gertjvr 

`LogContext` uses `ObjectWrapper` so that when an app using it calls into a secondary `AppDomain`, any enrichers pushed onto the context stack (which may be arbitrary, non-serializable, user-provided objects) remain in the source `AppDomain` and aren't serialized across with the call.

Am I correct in guessing that the application you're working on has made a call into another `AppDomain` at this point, either through remoting directly, or via SQL Server Management Objects?

Using a subclass of `ObjectHandle` that returns a custom `ILease` from `InitializeLifetimeService()` should fix this, as you suggest, but figuring out how to keep the lease alive long enough without leaking the object entirely will need some thought. Anyone have any ideas?

.NET 4.6 introduced `AsyncLocal`, which does not suffer from this problem (it uses `ExecutionContext` rather than `LogicalCallContext` for the state). We already support `AsyncLocal<>` with a build flag; I'm going to create a PR now that adds .NET 4.6 as an explicit target so that it's used instead of this horrendous API.

Which .NET Framework version are you running, Alexy?

issue.title: Use AsyncLocal rather than LogicalCallContext on .NET 4.6
issue.body: Back `LogContext` with the newer `AsyncLocal` where available (NET 4.6+) to avoid remoting issues. #835.

body:
Thanks for the great reply, appreciate the feedback.

> Yes, we use remoting. Are you sure that the problem pops up only in remoting scenarios?

I believe the problematic `ObjectHandle` lease only starts after a cross-appdomain call. All 2.0+ builds include this code, so the situations in which it becomes an issue must be fairly limited or we'd be flooded with reports by now (see more info further below).

> Ah, one more thing: a custom wrapper class or ObjectHandle descendant will need Serilog assembly in the target AppDomain to be deserialized. What if Serilog is not deployed there?

Only if the target appdomain uses Serilog's `LogContex`, otherwise the `ObjectHandle` is never `Unwrap()`ped.

> If you're OK with custom wrapper class, then I'd suggest infinite lease time + explicit disconnection via RemotingServices.Disconnect, something like this:

The copying behaviour of `LogicalCallContext` will make it hard for one single thread, that might be emptying the `LogContext`, to be sure that the `ObjectHandle` isn't still active on another logical thread. Or at least, I'd be cautious asserting anything about when the `ObjectHandle` can be disposed, because there are so many potential (mis-)usage patterns, and this API is a pain to work with.

> I'm running .NET 4.6 so using AsyncLocal is not a problem. But I'm a bit confused about ExecutionContext... I believe it includes logical call context as a part of it, doesn't it?

`ExecutionContext` is there in 4.5 but the members supporting `AsyncLocal` aren't (AFAICT).

I'll merge the 4.6 fix now and leave this issue open for discussion.

@yallie build `2.2.1-dev-00697` including the 4.6 fix is now on NuGet; it's otherwise close to identical to what is on `master`, so if you can confirm it addresses the issue for you we can push it through to a release build posthaste.

> The exception looks like someone from secondary domain attempted to use LogContext.

I think you're right, the call goes through proxies.

I believe random slot name should be ok: an ObjectHandle will leak into other domains, but no one will try to access it.

I've found it, it was not that random, but good enough to prevent the problem. Even the text was extremely precise, it my mistake it was reverted afterwards.

 Use per AppDomain slot name, so other domain won't accidentally unwrap object reference.
https://github.com/serilog/serilog/pull/733/commits/3b55d2dbcefefc97fe0db37258195190bb4a9d5b
@nblumhardt if you don't need display friendly name (I think you don't), then that's fine. I still hope we did bullet-proof remoting version and this is just a small mistake.
